messageBody:
> The most common mistake that prevents unifying public and published is
> excessive package differentiation. Too often code is separated into
> more packages than it needs to be. As I said earlier, this should be
> less of a problem in future JDKs once package access can be extended
> into subpackages.

Our system has around of half a million lines of code in 80+ CVS modules. We
use a lot of dependency injection to manage our code dependencies. I don't
know how you would do this without public classes and methods.

Or customers just care about a very small API, though. We started to manage
the *published* API by only publishing interfaces and some factories in
specific modules (everything public *in those modules* is published).

How does that sound to you?

Cheers, Ilja
